maml:description.maml:para: Expand the virtual machine members of a VM Group

When using VM groups, such as with Get-VMGroup, the resulting object displays nested VM or Management collections. But often, the whole point of a group is to make it easier to work with the collected virtual machines. This command will expand all virtual machines in a given group. You can also return a simple list of the virtual machine names.

maml:Description.maml:para: A VM group name.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to use with Computername.
You can filter your results by a group type. The default is all groups.
Return a text list of virtual machine names. The list will be of unique virtual machine names.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to use with Computername.
You can filter your results by a group type. The default is all groups.
Return a text list of virtual machine names. The list will be of unique virtual machine names.
A VM group name.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Expand-VMGroup -Name company
VMGroup Name State Uptime Status Computername ------- ---- ----- ------ ------ ------------ Company DOM1 Running 4.04:08:12.7640000 Operating normally HV-Master Company WIN10 Running 4.04:08:13.0420000 Operating normally HV-Master Company SRV1 Running 4.04:08:12.5300000 Operating normally HV-Master Company SRV2 Running 4.04:08:12.3590000 Operating normally HV-Master

dev:remarks.maml:para: Display all the virtual machines in the Company VM Group.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Expand-VMGroup -GroupType ManagementCollectionType -Computername HV01
VMGroup Name State Uptime Status Computername ------- ---- ----- ------ ------ ------------ Master Fedora28 Off 00:00:00 Operating normally HV01 Master WIN10 Running 21:54:42.5620000 Operating normally HV01 Master SRV1 Running 21:54:42.5620000 Operating normally HV01 Master SRV2 Running 21:54:42.8620000 Operating normally HV01 Master DOM1 Running 21:54:42.7720000 Operating normally HV01 Master SRV3 Running 21:54:43.2430000 Operating normally HV01

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all virtual machines in management collection groups on server HV01.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Expand-VMGroup -Name CompanyMembers -list WIN10 SRV1 SRV2

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the virtual machine names as a list from the CompanyMembers group.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Expand-VMGroup -Name CompanyMembers -list | Get-VMIPAddress
Name IPAddress MACAddress Switch Computername ---- --------- ---------- ------ ------------ WIN10 192.168.3.100 00155D0A364F LabNet HV-Master SRV1 192.168.3.50 00155D0A3650 LabNet HV-Master SRV2 192.168.3.51 00155D0A3651 LabNet HV-Master

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the list of virtual machines from CompanyMembers and pipe to Get-VMIPAddress.

maml:description.maml:para: Find a VM Group by name and/or group type

This command is very similar to Get-VMGroup and is not much more than a "wrapper" function for that command. The primary difference is that you can use this command to limit groups to a specific type. Although the default is to find all VM groups.

maml:Description.maml:para: A VM group ID.
Connect to a remote Hyper-V host using an existing CimSession.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
You can filter results by the VM group type. The default is all groups.
The name of a VM Group.
Connect to a remote Hyper-V host using an existing CimSession.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
You can filter results by the VM group type. The default is all groups.
Connect to a remote Hyper-V host using an existing CimSession.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
You can filter results by the VM group type. The default is all groups.
A VM group ID.
The name of a VM Group.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Find-VMGroup -GroupType ManagementCollectionType -computername HV-Master
Name : Company InstanceId : cb355d34-3dd6-4e31-ba2c-53470b95fc9c GroupType : ManagementCollectionType VMMembers : VMGroupMembers : {CompanyDC, CompanyMembers} CimSession : CimSession: . ComputerName : HV-Master IsDeleted : False
Name : Master InstanceId : d105e734-0e00-4eb0-a0c8-6c6e21c7956c GroupType : ManagementCollectionType VMMembers : VMGroupMembers : {CompanyDC, LinuxVMs, CompanyMembers} CimSession : CimSession: . ComputerName : HV-Master IsDeleted : False

maml:description.maml:para: Get virtual machine IP v4 information

This command is designed to get the IPv4 address for a given set of Hyper-V virtual machines. It assumes a single network adapter in each virtual machine with a single IPv4 address. The command has not been tested with other networking configurations such as NIC teaming.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a Hyper-V virtual machine name
Connect to a Hyper-V host using an existing CIMSession.
Enter a Hyper-V virtual machine name
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to use with Computername.
Connect to a Hyper-V host using an existing CIMSession.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to use with Computername.
Enter a Hyper-V virtual machine name

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> get-vmipaddress win10 -computername HV-Master
Name IPAddress MACAddress Switch Computername ---- --------- ---------- ------ ------------ WIN10 192.168.3.100 00155D0A364F LabNet HV-Master

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get IP address information for the Win10 virtual machine running on HV-Master.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-VMState -state running -CimSession $cs | Get-VMIPAddress
Name IPAddress MACAddress Switch Computername ---- --------- ---------- ------ ------------ DOM1 192.168.3.10 00155D4E720E LabNet HV-01 SRV1 192.168.3.50 00155D4E7210 LabNet HV-01 SRV2 192.168.3.51 00155D4E7211 LabNet HV-01 SRV3 192.168.3.60 00155D4E7212 LabNet HV-01 WIN10 192.168.3.100 00155D4E720F LabNet HV-01

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all running virtual machines using an existing CIMsession and pipe to Get-VMIPAddress.

maml:description.maml:para: This command gets memory settings for a given Hyper-V virtual machine. All memory values are in MB.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the virtual machine or a Hyper-V virtual machine object. This parameter has an alias of "VM"
The name of the Hyper-V server to query. The default is the local host.
An alternate credential to be used with the Computername.
The name of the virtual machine or a Hyper-V virtual machine object. This parameter has an alias of "VM"
An existing CIMSession object to a Hyper-V host.
A virtual machine object.
A virtual machine ID.
An existing CIMSession object to a Hyper-V host.
A virtual machine ID.
The name of the Hyper-V server to query. The default is the local host.
An alternate credential to be used with the Computername.
The name of the virtual machine or a Hyper-V virtual machine object. This parameter has an alias of "VM"
A virtual machine object.
An existing CIMSession object to a Hyper-V host.
The name of the Hyper-V server to query. The default is the local host.
An alternate credential to be used with the Computername.
A virtual machine ID.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-VM Win10 | Get-VMMemorySummary
Name Dynamic AssignedMB DemandMB StartMB MinMB MaxMB ---- ------- ---------- -------- ------- ----- ----- WIN10 True 2048 880 2048 2048 1048576

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get a memory report for a single virtual machine. Note that the output is formatted as a table by default.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-VMMemorySummary dom1 | select *
Name : DOM1 Dynamic : True Assigned : 2048 Demand : 962 Startup : 2048 Minimum : 2048 Maximum : 1048576 Buffer : 20 Priority : 50 Computername : BOVINE320 Date : 6/4/2019 12:23:27 PM

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-VMState -State Running -ComputerName HV01 | Get-VMMemorySummary | Where-object {$_.demand -ge 1024} | Select-object * | Out-Gridview -title "Memory Report"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get a memory report for all running virtual machines on server HV01 that have a memory demand greater than 1024MB and display the results with Out-Gridview.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a virtual machine by its state.

One of the drawbacks to the Get-VM command in the Hyper-V module is that it provides no filtering mechanism on the state, such as running. If you often find yourself running Get-VM and piping to Where-Object to only get running or stopped virtual machines, this command will simplify that process. The default behavior is to display all running virtual machines.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of a virtual machine.
An existing CIMSession to a Hyper-V host.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
The virtual machine state to filter for.
A virtual machine ID.
An existing CIMSession to a Hyper-V host.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
The virtual machine state to filter for.
The virtual machine state to filter for.
An existing CIMSession to a Hyper-V host.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
A virtual machine ID.
The name of a virtual machine.
The virtual machine state to filter for.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-VMState -State Off -ComputerName HV-01
Name State CPUUsage(%) MemoryAssigned(M) Uptime Status Version ---- ----- ----------- ----------------- ------ ------ ------- Fedora28 Off 0 0 00:00:00 Operating normally 8.3 WS2019_Base Off 0 0 00:00:00 Operating normally 9.0

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all virtual machines on HV-01 that are not running.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-VMState -computername HV-Master | Get-VMMemory
VMName DynamicMemoryEnabled Minimum(M) Startup(M) Maximum(M) ------ -------------------- ---------- ---------- ---------- DOM1 True 2048 2048 1048576 SRV1 True 1024 2048 1048576 SRV2 True 1024 2048 1048576 SRV3 True 1024 1024 1048576 SRV4 True 512 4096 1048576 WIN10 True 2048 2048 1048576

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all running virtual machines on HV-Master and pipe the virtual machine objects to Get-VMMemory.

maml:description.maml:para: Connect to virtual machine using VMConnect.

This is a PowerShell command to make it easier to connect to a virtual machine console using the VMConnect.exe command line tool. You must run this under an account that has admin rights on the remote Hyper-V host.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a Hyper-V virtual machine name
The name of the Hyper-V host.
The name of the Hyper-V host.
Enter a Hyper-V virtual machine name

dev:remarks.maml:para: Launch VMConnect and connect to virtual machine SRV1 on HV-01.

maml:description.maml:para: Open a virtual machine using Remote Desktop.

Connect to a given virtual machine using a remote desktop connection. This assumes a Windows operating system on the virtual machine and it has been configured to allow remote desktop connections. The connection is made via the virtual machine's IP address. If connecting to a virtual machine on a remote computer it must have a publicly accessible IP address and interface.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a Hyper-V virtual machine name. The virtual machine needs a publicly accessible IP address.
Connect to remote desktop session used for administering a remote computer.
The name of the Hyper-V host.
Run in full screen mode.
Connect to remote desktop session used for administering a remote computer.
The name of the Hyper-V host.
Run in full screen mode.
Enter a Hyper-V virtual machine name. The virtual machine needs a publicly accessible IP address.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Connect to the virtual machine Win10 on the local machine via remote desktop full screen. You may be prompted for credentials.

maml:description.maml:para: Start all members of a VM group that are not already running.
This command will expand virtual machine members of a VM group and start the virtual machine if it is not already running.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the VM Group.
Start the virtual machines in a background job.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
Write the virtual machine object to the pipeline
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Start the virtual machines in a background job.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.
The name of the VM Group.
Write the virtual machine object to the pipeline
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Start-VMGroup company -Computername HV-Master -Passthru
Name State CPUUsage(%) MemoryAssigned(M) Uptime Status Version ---- ----- ----------- ----------------- ------ ------ ------- SRV1 Running 0 0 00:00:00 Operating normally 9.0 SRV2 Running 0 0 00:00:00 Operating normally 9.0

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start the members of the Company VM group on HV-Master that are not already running.

maml:description.maml:para: Stop all members of a VM group that are not already running.
This command will expand virtual machine members of a VM group and stop the virtual machine if it running.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of a VM group.
Stop the virtual machines using a background job.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.

Specifies that the shutdown of the virtual machine is to be forced. If the virtual machine has applications with unsaved data, the virtual machine has five minutes to save data and shut down. If the virtual machine is locked, it is shut down immediately.
Write the virtual machine object to the pipeline.
Specifies that the virtual machine is to be saved.
Specifies that the virtual machine is to be turned off.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Stop the virtual machines using a background job.
The name of a Hyper-V host.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
An alternate credential to be used with Computername.

Specifies that the shutdown of the virtual machine is to be forced. If the virtual machine has applications with unsaved data, the virtual machine has five minutes to save data and shut down. If the virtual machine is locked, it is shut down immediately.
The name of a VM group.
Write the virtual machine object to the pipeline.
Specifies that the virtual machine is to be saved.
Specifies that the virtual machine is to be turned off.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stop all members of the Master VM group on HV-01 using a background job.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Stop-VMGroup linuxvms -Save -Passthru -Computername hv-master
Name State CPUUsage(%) MemoryAssigned(M) Uptime Status Version ---- ----- ----------- ----------------- ------ ------ ------- CentOS Saved 0 978 00:10:40.4110000 Operating normally 8.0

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stop all running members of the LinuxVMS group on HV-Master, saving their state.
